name: steel production, electric, chromium steel 18/8 | steel, chromium steel 18/8 | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/1482/documentation

Background:;This activity represents the production of stainless steel (Type 304, aka. 18/8; assumed composition 68.6% Fe, 9.3% Ni, 19.0% Cr and 0.08% C) in a two-stage process. Raw materials (charge chrome, pig iron, carbon steel scrap and ferronickel) are loaded into an electric arc furnace (EAF) and melted together. The composition of the charge corresponds to that of the desired steel product, besides the carbon content. The molten metal is then removed from the EAF and transferred to an argon-oxygen decarburisation (AOD) refining vessel, in which the amounts of impurities, principally carbon, are reduced to the desired levels. The purified molten metal is then continuously cast into stainless steel slabs (Norgate et al., 2004).;;Modelling approach:;Data on the use of electricity, oxygen, argon and electrodes were taken from Norgate et al. (2004) and are specific to stainless steel production. The amounts of steel by-products (dusts, sludges and slags) that are produced are based on measured data from plants worldwide reported by worldsteel (2010). Also based on worldsteel (2010), the following internal recycling rates (i.e. returned as an input to the process after it has been produced) were assumed: EAF slag, 3%; secondary metallurgy slag, 14%; and dust, 10%. All other data were taken from the IPPC Best Available Technology report from the European Commission (Remus et al., 2013) and are representative of typical low- and un-alloyed steel production in an electric arc furnace in Europe. Note that where only data ranges were provided, the geometric mean of reported values was used here.;;References:;Norgate, Jahanshahi, S. & Rankin, W. J. (2004). Alternative routes to stainless steel - a life cycle approach. Proceedings: Tenth International Ferroalloys Congress; INFACON X: ‘Transformation through Technology’, 1 – 4 February 2004, Cape Town, South Africa.;Remus, R., Aguado-Monsonet, M. A., Roudier, S. & Samcho, L. D. (2013). JRC reference report - Best available techniques (BAT) reference document for iron and steel production. Joint Research Centre - European Commission, Luxemboug.;Worldsteel (2010). Steel industry by-products. World Steel Association: Brussels, Belgium.

At the gate of the steelmaking plant with the arrival of the ferrous scrap.

At the gate of the steelmaking plant with the cast steel ready for transport to manufacturers and fabricators.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/241:Manufacture of basic iron and steel/2410:Manufacture of basic iron and steel

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are mostly compiled from reports published between 2005 and 2010 but are considered representative of modern operations.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data are taken from electric arc furnace plants across Europe and are considered representative of the average situation across Europe.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Represents average European technology; furnace with 4th hole and secondary metallurgy
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Data were taken from direct measurements at blast furnace plants across Europe.

Note that there may be mass imbalances in the dataset. This is because the values represent the average situation in steelmaking  many different plants and have not been augmented or adjusted. Similarily, these values represent the situation post-ventilation/off-gas management, i.e. it is not the mass of carbon, for instance, that is produced that is reported but the amount that is actually, on average, emitted to the environment considering an average mix of steelmaking, technologies, off-gas management approaches, and internal recovery (recycling) or utilisation rates at integrated steelmakers in Europe. 

It should also be noted that data on radionucleid emissions to air, e.g. of Pollonium 210 and Lead 210, were not available and have therefore not been inventoried here.
